Summary:
The patient is a 48-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), congestive heart failure (CHF), and mechanical aortic valve. He was admitted with progressive dyspnea and treated with steroids and diuretics. The patient required intubation and was transferred back to the MICU due to increased dyspnea and tachypnea. He has completed a 7-day course of vancomycin and piperacillin-tazobactam for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP). The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C (98.9°F), heart rate of 76 bpm, blood pressure of 112/52 mmHg, respiratory rate of 21 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100% on a nasal cannula. The patient's fluid balance is negative 2.9 liters since midnight. Laboratory results show anemia with a hematocrit of 27.4%, elevated white blood cell count, and normal liver and kidney function. The patient's coagulation profile is pending. The patient's medical history includes schizophrenia, psychotic disorder, diabetes mellitus type 2, and chronic venous stasis with potential risk for infection. The patient is currently on heparin sodium, furosemide, and other medications as per the ICU care plan.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 48-year-old male with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), congestive heart failure (CHF), and mechanical aortic valve. He was admitted with progressive dyspnea and treated with steroids and diuretics. The patient required intubation due to increased dyspnea and tachypnea. He underwent a 7-day course of vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam for hospital-acquired pneumonia. A PICC line was placed but may no longer be necessary. The patient completed a steroid taper today.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Respiratory Failure - The patient has severe chronic COPD/CHF and was brought back to the MICU for flash pulmonary edema. He was extubated without difficulty on [**2145-7-14**].
2. Hypotension - The patient is normotensive overnight and has no acute issues.
3. Anemia - The patient's current hematocrit (Hct) is 27.0, showing a slight decrease from his previous Hct of 29. Monitoring of Hct will continue.
4. Mechanical Aortic Valve - The patient's goal INR is 2.5, but his current INR is 3.5. He will be restarted on warfarin when his partial thromboplastin time (PTT) is closer to the goal range of 60-80 seconds. PENDING coagulation results.
5. Lower Extremity Skin Changes and Ear/Facial Wound - The patient has chronic venous stasis with potential for infection. Wound care, lidocaine, and lower extremity elevation will be continued. The patient should avoid reinjuring the affected areas.
6. History of Schizophrenia and Psychotic Disorder - The patient has had frequent episodes of leaving the hospital against medical advice (AMA). If this happens again, the patient's capacity will need to be addressed. Trazodone has been held at a dose of 300 mg per night due to the patient appearing somnolent.
7. Diabetes Mellitus Type 2 - The patient's current insulin regimen will be continued.
8. Lines/Tubes: The patient has an arterial line, multi-lumen central venous catheter, and a 20-gauge peripheral IV line.
9. Prophylaxis: Prophylaxis for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), stress ulcer, and ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) will be continued.
10. Code status: The patient is designated as full code.
11. Disposition: The patient will be transferred to the floor today.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure - The patient may experience recurrent respiratory failure due to his severe chronic COPD/CHF.
2. Hypotension - The patient may develop hypotension if there are any acute issues or if his cardiac function worsens.
3. Anemia - The patient's anemia may worsen if his Hct continues to decrease.
4. Mechanical Aortic Valve - The patient may have an increased risk of bleeding due to his elevated INR.
5. Lower Extremity Skin Changes and Ear/Facial Wound - The patient may develop further skin breakdown and infection if proper wound care is not maintained.
6. History of Sch
